all_paragraphs: Data science and machine learning careers are still relatively new and I have previously written an article on the problems data scientists often encounter in their jobs because some companies do not know how to use them to their fullest potential.

Interestingly, having given many technical interviews, I’ve seen that many potential data scientists don’t know how to present themselves well. This is especially true for those with little to no experience in industry (fresh graduate of a data science Msc etc.).

This is a huge shame as I (personally) genuinely want everyone to do their best and get the jobs they want, but I do feel bad when I can’t find strong reasons to get them onto the next rung of the recruitment process. I would imagine this holds true for many other people in my position as well. They want you to succeed but we need to know you can before we invest time for an interview. Oddly they aren’t cost free to the business, if you consider you’ll be meeting 2–3 people for an hour each this can quickly add up in lost productivity.

To put a finger on this costs we can make an order of magnitude estimate. A senior data scientist is £ 60,805 a year (£ 31/hour) with a data scientist generally commanding £ 46,820 a year (£ 24/hour). If you consider the senior data scientist will probably have a total of an hours’ worth of phone conversations with you (or about you to a recruiter) and if you pass that you will then have an interview for an hour with two people (a team data scientist performing technical interviewing and the senior doing some softer skills and fit interviews) followed by a 30 minute private group discussion afterwards about the result of the interview. They have then made an investment of 4 hours or around £ 114 in salary costs in you. However, this is a minimum cost because you would need to factor in additional hours or other factors such as HR personnel etc.
So, an interview is an expensive investment in gauging you, making it important everyone does the best they can.

Following on from my own lessons on survivorship bias, instead of listing what a successful applicant did right, I’ve listed the mistakes of those that never got very far in the process. My hope is that this will help you avoid the common mistakes I see in over half of every application I get across my desk.
I’ll expand on each, but the general list is:

Note: These are based on my own personal experiences and views combined with talking to others about their interview experiences. Different people and/or companies may have different experiences/opinions.

This may seem obvious, but I do see this, and it is an instant “no no”. Luckily, I rarely see blatant lying, but I have seen the case where someone claimed to have headed up a group, only to find the interviewer actually knows the head of that group and confronted them on this mid interview.

Trust is a great commodity as you’ll be expected to convey an image of integrity and professionalism when representing the company. Therefore, you don’t want to do anything to make them doubt you can do that. So, what I mean by “do not lie” here is an attempt to distort or disguise something your presenting about yourself to an extent that you are seen to be untrustworthy.
This “truth stretching" covers things like:

Taking credit is often seen where a MOOC or other course is passed off as original work, maybe even suggesting it was a real data science project for industry. Rather than capstone courses (i.e. you are given data and little guidance on the solution) these are the ones where you are following structured course material and the solutions are readily available.

The flaw in presenting them in this way is that any reasonably sized data science group will probably have had someone who has already taken it and therefore will notice the similarities in what you are talking about. They can generally weed these out and while not an outright no, it might be dimly viewed depending on how bad the faux pas was. The same is true for smaller groups as they often still possess that core nucleus of highly experienced data scientists (some of whom may have written the courses you are quoting).
Don’t get me wrong, I would expect anyone to make the best and most impressive case about themselves (e.g. bigging yourself up) and a show of confidence is good, but you can go too far.

If you list under “Work/Industrial/Professional Experience” a Kaggle, Coursera or edX course it will get a raised eyebrow. While all of those are great continued education and professional development, they rarely compare to the unique challenges of having a paying client or boss giving you a genuine problem to solve. The latter work is more impressive, but the former is good too. Just put it in the right place.

The most common areas of bullet point three (something that cannot have happened) are claims which lack basic fact checking. I.e. If you make a claim of 10 years of TensorFlow experience (released in 2015), don’t expect that to go down well. Also, if you say you have extreme attention to detail, make sure you do not have glaring formatting errors.

Any of these claims may get pointed out and you will feel embarrassed. Or you could argue you are in the right (as has happened), but if you cannot prove it then this will not work in your favour (see point three below).

Imagine you have just read a book and it never once mentioned anything to do with science fiction, despite you buying it from that section of the store. You read it all the way to the end hoping it would suddenly appear.
Now imagine reading a CV back to front and getting to the end to find it didn’t mention data science or machine learning once. How can you judge their skills?

If you want a data science job you need to mention it and go into details. I have seen many CV’s which go on for pages about things they have done but make no mention of machine learning algorithms, statistics or even python/R etc.

To be hired an interviewer needs to see that you know something about the subject area, and they need enough detail to know what experience level you are so you can be interviewed appropriately. For example, there is no point testing you on SQL if you have never used it. They could instead be testing you on a stronger area you have mentioned (it takes many kinds to build a good data science capability).
If you state “I used machine learning” tell me more. Make it a short but interesting story. For example:
“We utilised a machine learning solution to detect drain leaks by first applying PCA on Fourier transformed sound profiles. A final classification was given using a K-nearest neighbours.”
“We had a problem with leaking drains. Using machine learning we were able to detect them.”

The above solution is a little longer in length, but you have mentioned two things that will peak my interest and those are “how you did it” and “domain knowledge”. It helps to distinguish you as someone who knows how it works, and can design bespoke solutions, from someone who used an off the shelf program that you click and forget (e.g. it runs multiple models and selects the best with no expert oversight).

On the relevancy, make sure areas that are not relevant to data scientist are further down your CV. I was often taught to tailor my CV for every job I applied for and this would entail moving sections up that are more relevant, so they are seen first. If a potential boss is reading lots of CV’s a day, they will be short on attention, you will need to grab them early on. It also shows you possess one of the data science key skills which is to convey the key point of your findings clearly and quickly.

If you have a covering letter or statement, make it relevant. They perhaps only need to know you have 12 Aunts and have not eaten meat for 2 years as part of the ice breaking conversations at the start of your face to face interview.
With the huge explosion in data science, there is a temptation to put down all the buzzwords you can remember and hope those catch someone’s eye.

Since it is such a diverse field, putting down a lot of stuff will cast a large net but will cause raised eyebrows on whether you really are the magical unicorn of data science. If you are not, then you may struggle when queried and possibly alienate the interviewer (remember about stretching the truth?).

This is because interviewers have a habit that once they find a chink in your knowledge, they will chip at it and see how deep the void goes. This means you can spend 15–20 minutes of your interview being grilled on something you know little about, become super disheartened, feel embarrassed and the areas you are super strong at never get a look in.
The way to avoid this is to only ever write things on your CV that you feel you can defend if asked questions on.

I have certainly had the case where during a technical interview someone has struggled to do a SQL question I’ve set. However, when they stated it wasn’t something they normally do, I’ve pointed out the part of their application where they wrote it was. This is awkward for everyone and casts doubts on other areas of your CV that may in fact be solid.

Interviews are scary and believe it or not the interviewer is worried how it will go too (or at least I am). They want you to succeed and be the best data scientist you can because no one wants to sit through interviews for people who clearly cannot do the job.
If you get an interview you have clearly shown, you have enough promise to incur the cost to the business of setting up an interview.
To help you do the best these tips can help you:

In summary if you can write down how amazing you are and what experience you have in the field in a nicely digestible form then you are well on your way to demonstrating you can convey critical information well!
P.S. Also don’t be afraid to ask for feedback. You may not receive any and don’t be disheartened by that but any you do get is a precious commodity that’ll help pinpoint any weak areas.
